column4: when installing ubuntu, is there an option to put the boot loader onto a floppy instead of the mbr?
why dont you want it to touch the MBR?
i won't be using linux that much. windows will remain my primary partition, therefore it is unnecessary to add a bootloader
instead, have it install grub in the MBR then change your grub config to make Windows the default choice.
i prefer floppy, then i can simply select by inserting/removing it... it has always been a personal preference that i like...
unfortunately, the ubuntu installer doesn't allow that.
ok.. i guess i can just skip installing the bootloader, then put my own on the floppy
nm, i can install to floppy ... i found it in the installation docs
really? then i was wrong before then.
http://ftp.ubuntulinux.org/ubuntu/dists/warty/main/installer-i386/current/doc/manual/en/ch06s03.html#id2514188  ... look at 'other choice' in this section
that info applies to Ubuntu 4.10 which is two years old.
so you will need a CD with debian-installer on it i guess.
where can i find the info about which CDs have debian-installer on it?

if you want the more advanced installer, which that doc u mentioned talks about, you'll need the alternate CD.  It's easier to just install the standard way and edit the grub config file easily leter.
nah.. i don't mind.... i installed slackware 5 years ago.. so i think i can handle it :)
then i think u can handle it too :)
